rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: While he makes the class engaging and fun, he doesn't prepare you so well for tests. Study up for that final.

Clegg is always willing to help, all you have to do is ask. This class takes attendance based on clicker-questions which reflects your grade; go to class. All of the tests are from the homeworks and the clicker-questions. He puts lecture notes online so you don't need to take notes in class. Tests are harsh; KNOW ALL HWs and you'll be fine; AVG. B-

During lectures, Clegg is always doing some sort of exciting demonstration. The homework, clicker questions, and equations are what's on the test, and there is a lot of excess information in the lectures. You will understand the world better. SI sessions and office hours are extremely helpful. Take him to be challenged and rewarded.

Professor Clegg is amazing. His class is hard, so don't be surprised if you don't get an A or even a B. However, his office hours are amazing and he truly cares about whether or not you understand the subject material. I wish he would teach all of my science classes!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: PHYS 119 is tough. Henning was good one-on-one, but in the lecture hall is not too exciting to listen to. He'll tell you what you need to know but doesn't try to make it exciting for you. He also often rants on about why he's teaching how he's teaching instead of just teaching. He'll get the point across, but could easily just do it in fewer words.
Smart and funny guy who is really willing to work with you to help you figure things out.

Professor Henning is about as engaging a physics teacher can get. The lectures go by pretty fast. He's funny which makes the class better along with his ability to explain things. Definitely recommend.

There is a lot of homework. The lectures involve clickers and group disucssions, making it engaging. The labs can be a drag sometimes. There's a lot of material to cover, so it's important to make sure you don't get behind. He explains things pretty clearly.

Professor Henning certainly maximizes his 50 minutes.  Peppered with quirky physics humor, his teaching style is straightforward and well-paced. If you ever find yourself with a question, he happily spends a few minutes discussing it during or after class.  Certainly a good lecturer and highly recommend him for your physics course needs!

Dr. Henning worked hard to ensure the material was better explained and more intuitive than previous introductory level physics classes , and he largely succeeded. The class was difficult, but he seems to be working diligently to continually improve the course. Besides first time kinks, he has created an exemplary model for science classes.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Lopez is very nice and very willing to help if you go to office hours.  He isn't the clearest lecturer, but he's decent.  His tests are mostly concepts based, the calculations aren't hard, but the test average was still low.  They test that you get the big picture.  He curves and will bump you up if he sees you at office hours.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: No Comments

Truly horrible astronomy teacher. Poorly laid out class, fails to thoroughly cover exam material, "dumbs down" information to the point of being incomprehensible. She has daily quizzes that, more often than not, are not relevant to information being taught- one quiz problem asked what house the sun was in at the time (astrology, seriously?)

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Reichart was fantastic. There was very little homework and the material is super interesting. He's hilarious and I enjoyed his lectures. The class was an easy A but he does throw trick questions on exams. This class does involve math and physics but if you're fairly good at science then you'll  be fine.

This class was supposed to be an easy A, but when he told us top 25% of the class make an A I got really upset. I made a C+ in this class because a lot of students cheated on the final and pushed my grade back. Worst grading scale ever, especially when I worked my butt off for this class. Do NOT recommend for fulfilling a gen-ed.

Reichart is a prof that knows the material backwards and forwards. He's a great guy and hilarious. All of the lectures are found online. The tests are copy and paste from the webassign, just use the webassign answer key and you're good to go. It's a very easy class, he drops lowest test and 2 HW grades. Would recommend for nonscience majors.
Took his Astro 101 class. Gives very clear and informative lectures, but gives tests often on specific trivia that was never covered in class.

Dr. Reichart is an extremely qualified, funny, and kind professor. His lectures are usually very interesting and (except for the telescope selection unit) the material covered is fascinating and will help you better understand the world around you. I took this course purely because it sounded interesting, and would definitely recommend it.

I went to the lectures and used an allowed "cheat sheet"  full of lecture notes and I only passed 1 test. Everything is graded on a curve which sounds great right? Except in any other science course a 70 is a C. In this class a 70 was an F. You had to make in the 80's to get a C. Tests were not on lecture material. They were mostly physics problems
Reichart is a great guy who is very passionate. The class itself is not hard. Just do the homework and make cheat sheets (he allows one per test) for the tests and you will be just fine.

The class sounds like it would be easy, but the cheat sheets barely help because he asks trick questions. Using the textbook to do the homework will get you a zero, he seems to appreciate only his own ideas. When asking him for help he replies with one sentence or nothing at all, and if you go to office hours you better come prepared

Reichart is adorable and funny.  He is very knowledgable about the subject, and you can see that in his excitement for the course.  Class is insanely easy and very interesting.  He drops your lowest test and homework, and if you do an extra credit paper you get a second homework dropped - plus you can bring notes to exams.  Math is minimal and easy

If you are at UNC and looking to take care of your science requirement, this is probably the best science class to take. The professor lets you bring in "cheat sheets" with formulas and information for the multiple choice tests, which are very helpful. Beware - he likes to test on facts/trivia that he mentions once in class and never again.
Reichart he's hard and there's a lot of studying by yourself...

This was a fantastic course, and I absolutely enjoyed Reichart as my professor!!  He's funny, clear in his lectures, and he makes the topics interesting! Take this if you need a science requirement, you'll love it!

Lectures are entertaining, and if you don't want to go he will post them online. If you go to office hours he will all but give you the answers on the homework. He is very very helpful! The only negative things is that he uses web assign, which costs an extra $60, but he will let you use older versions of the text book.

Reichart is a good prof and his lectures were interesting. However, he was not very organized and his notes in class were terrible. The class is graded on a curve, so it only depends how well you do against others. Not a very hard class at all, and easy to get an A or B. Take him if you're interested in astro.

If you are interested at all in astronomy or need a GPA padding course, take Astro 101 with Professor Reichart!  He is extremely funny during lectures (albeit nerdy funny) and the homework is  easy and not time-consuming.  The tests aren't extremely difficult and you get a cheat sheet.  He drops your lowest test grade and 2 lowest homework grades!!

Boring lectures, trick questions on tests and webassign homeworks. only good thing is that you get to have a cheat sheet for exams. Dont take this if you don't have to. He also grades on a weird curve that could hurt you more than help you. Sometimes a 97 on the homeworks is a B. He also doesn't do his own office hours.
Professor Reichart is great! He gives interesting, engaging lectures. All homework is online and all the tests are multiple choice.  He is not very personable however.
We <3 Reichart!!!!

He may be interesting, but he is the most uncaccessible professor! He does not relally like to give A's to his students. He only loves to hear himself. Never avaible during office hours, by the time he responds, you already figured it out, and that could be 2 days. His lab instructor though,  Dr Couze is terrific. By the way, got  a B.
He's awesome. Take the class just to have him. Lecture Notes aren't great, but tests come straight from the online notes and hw, so use that, and take advantage of his cheat sheet rules on each test

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: He is a great professor during lecture. He plays less of an administrative role because the class is team-taught. He is clear and can teach well. The test are hard, and you pretty much need to have taken physics in high school to get an A.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Prof. Erickcek is a wonderful professor- she knows exactly what she's going to say in each of her lectures and explains things really well. Her problem sets are hard (don't leave them until the night before) but she was always really helpful in her office hours. If you have any interest in astronomy or astrophysics, definitely take 301 with her!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: A remarkable fount of knowledge.  He's the rare theorist who knows a great deal of experimental detail as well and can answer every bizarre question we dream up.

CRE's da Bomb! He's too advanced for any one text.  You can't stop him.  He is like a white hole (opposite of a black hole) that spews forth knowledge whether you want it or not.  Most people want it.  Show me another professor who can tell you the number of grams in the Sun and I'll show you an accelerated observer with a vanishing Riemann tensor!

Here are the facts about Chuck and E&M II. (1) Chuck is extremely lucid. (2) Chuck is slightly insane.  (3) Chuck truly is our Uber-Nerd-Messiah! (4) Jackson (text) is daunting, but reliable.  (5) Chuck will make up his own problems to unnecessarily supplement this tome.  (6) Chuck knows about a hundred digits of pi and likes Pink Floyd.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Office hours are helpful to a degree. Don't take me wrong, the physics is hard in general. but, she prides herself in giving exams with the highest score in a class of 50 ppl being an 82 and not curving.considers a B or greater to be stellar work. did 450 practice problems just for the final. Still made a B+.(from the organic student who makes ~95)

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: One of the hardest classes I've had while at UNC. Very few people have an A in this class.

Bad teacher, not very helpful, and tests were poorly written and did not test learning well. I went into this class interested in physics and came out uninterested. I had taken a physics class prior to this one as well, which was much better.
Not clear at all, wastes time during lecture, never says what work she wants on exams then counts off for not doing things exactly her way.

Seriously, UNC, hire a beaver and replace her. It would do so much better than her in lecturing. Not helpful, incredibly monotone and boring, inconsistent and opaque grading system. But too bad, she's the only one available for the course

Showed poor understanding of material, class consisted of only clicker questions, tests were graded harshly when the student got the correct answer but used a different method than the teacher expected.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Very boring, she doesnt really explain anything. Her lectures are straight from the book. The tests are easy if you study but nothing like the examples from class. you will basically have to teach yourself.
If you see Dolan as professor, change your class or wait for the next semester.

Going to lectures is basically useless. The questions on the test are very different than the examples used in class or the homework problems. She speaks very low, so to hear anything she says you must sit in the front. Very, very boring.
Just as said before, easy tests, lecture not really helpful if you can understand the book, I recomend this prof if all you need is the credit.

Her lectures are basically comprised of a lot of examples.  I skipped a lot of classes b/c I kept falling asleep.  Her tests are moderate to easy (depends if you study and memorize the equations), but there are only 10 MC... so if you miss one, it hurts a lot!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Perfect FYS for a physics major looking to get into research and one of the best professors you could get to know to get involved.  He gives interesting lectures on super cool material and his own work.  Also, he is pretty hilarious.  Don't take this class if political correctness is more important than enjoying your education.

Dr.K is the coolest professor ever.  He's very knowledgeable about electronics, science, and most topics.  His TA grades the lab reports fairly harshly, but it's good experience for later science classes.  If your considering taking phys52: just do it!

Dr. K is a nice and funny person but don't take this class if you aren't already experienced in physics and computer science. I like Dr. K, but as a professor he isn't super helpful unless you are already good at the subject. Also, the labs are graded pretty harshly and you will not finish the labs during lab time usually (you don't get lab cred)
Dr. K is one of the best professors I have ever had. He is incredibly kind and a really great professor. I was lucky to take his FYS which allowed for more interaction.

Professor K is an incredible teacher. He is more than just an instructor. Professor K is a mentor and a guide that will be there for the rest of your time at UNC. The skills I learned in his class (PHYS 52) where invaluable and although it is challenging, I would not hesitate to take it again. Love the man, he has a heart of gold.
I've graduated, and my opinion hasn't changed.  Dr. K is the best professor at UNC.

Professor Karwowski is an amazing teacher.  He was always available for help, funny, taught the material very well, and made my mornings so much brighter.  I'd strongly recommend taking any of his courses, he's fun to be around.

Absolutely fantastic.  He makes going to class something you look forward to.  He'll throw a ton of work at you initially but its not hard to make an A if you apply yourself.  In my opinion hes by far the best professor at UNC.

Definitely not the teacher to take if you haven't had physics before. He expects you to have some background in physics before coming into the class. His lectures weren't really planned that well either.  That being said if you have a good background in physics I would go with him. He does assign a weekly homework assignment, but it's not that bad.

Karwowski makes getting up at 8 AM bearable.  His class was not as hard as he "jokes" that it is, I personally felt it should have been harder(this might have motivated me to not do my homework the night it was due every time.  do your homework early, and in different locations, you'll meet people.  this class was very social)

Hugon was the best professor I have had at UNC.  If you get the chance, take his class!  He will be a very difficult teacher during the year, as his problem sets rae meant to really challenge you, but his tests and exams were not horribly difficult and he rives some favoralbe curving towards the end.  He will also keep you laughing and engaged!!!

Hugon is one of the best professors at UNC. He assigns hard homework, but his tests are pretty easy, and he counts the PHYS 116 lab for a very small portion of your grade. He is friendly, helpful, and full of irreverent humor.

Hugon is an amazing professor.  I was in the 116 course for people intending to major in Physics.  It was very difficult, but a lot of fun.  We didn't use the book at all, and he made up his own (very difficult) homework problems, but they were always quite entertaining.

This is the old phys 101 (electronics).  He's a great guy and very willing to help you, but the class is slightly frustrating.  Often he is not clear in class, and he assigns extremely hard homework to force you to figure out what he hasn't covered in lectures on your own.
He is the best professor I have ever had! I recommend him to anyone new to physics. His lectures are entertaining and has many office hours and review sessions.
I consider Hugon to be the best teacher i have had to date at unc
This was definetly one of the hardest classes that I have taken here. But he was a great guy. VERY VERY entertaining and could relate well to students.  I definetly reccomend this class.
This is the  best professor I've ever had!
No Comments

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: This guy is completely disorganized. He makes simple problems extremely disorganized and sometimes gets himself confused and contradicts what he said earlier. When he taught, he made everyone else more and more confused. Very very nice guy, though.

Champagne is okay, BUT... PHYS 114 is one of the most terribly organized courses I've ever taken. Final exam average: 58. The Mastering assignments had nothing to do with lectures OR exams! Exams were unreasonably tough and always a time crunch. And the studios... long, repetitive, and agonizingly boring. Grading criteria unclear.
He is awesome. He's really chill and in studio he's super helpful and never makes you feel stupid for not understanding. He's also a really good lecturer and describes physics in relatable terms.

Dr. Champagne is really cool. He'll go far out of his way to explain anything you're confused about. The class was difficult for me, but as physics classes go, it wasn't bad. I'd definitely recommend taking this course or any other with him.
He's a good professor and is willing to help explain things.  I would recommend him.

best part of the course was learning his own derivations.  it felts great to know that there are other ways to derive formulas from the textbook.  clear and really helpful.  go to class.  notes are gold.
ignore the 12/8 comment down there.  don't take your anger out on the prof, he's cool.  4/15 comment is more accurate.
he's a very nice guy.  I enjoy his lectures although sometimes they are no more helpful than reading the book.
This guy has the corniest jokes and smells kind of funny! Avoid him at all costs

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I took PHYS 118 with Sean over summer session 1, and I have got to say that he is one of the best science professors I have had at UNC. If you don't understand something, he will explain it again and again (in a different way each time), until you understand it. He encourages questions, and is a very fair professor.

When you are new to the material, you may get a sense that Sean's explanations are hasty and incomplete but you'll second guess yourself: "maybe it's just me, maybe I should focus on this lecture and then I'll get it". Wrong - his explanations truly are hasty and incomplete. Come to class, take detailed notes, but learn from TEXTBOOKS W SOLUTIONS!
Respectable professor. If you need help, he will make time. Behind the sarcasm, he's a great professor.
Horrible lecturer.  Makes you feel terrible for asking questions. Avoid.
Made it clear from day 1 he didn't care about this class or anyone in it. Scheduled appointments with him 4 times and he didn't bother to show up every time.
One of the best professors at the University.
Boo.
I had a lot of trouble in this class but I'm not a Physics person. Sometimes he didn't explain things very well. But he was really nice and laid back. A lot of people got As and Bs in there.

Sean is a very awsome and funny guy, however he was a pretty horrible 101 teacher (but he hates that class, so he is a much better teacher in 103).  He makes you feel like he hates answering your questions and that you are really really dumb, but in fact he loves when you ask him questions and just likes picking on you, that's his natural state :P.

Very approachable and friendly. Truly cares about you understanding the material. Lectures are difficult to decipher sometimes, and he has a habit of making you feel dumb if you don't immediately grasp concepts. Office hours are a must. Tests are HARD, but there's a generous curve.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I think I fell asleep in the class almost every day.  Class is very boring and lecture material is completely irrelevant to assignments. He can be funny, but you are usually asleep for those parts.  No clue on how he calculates final grades.
This was a seminar class on Peak Oil. Cecil droned on and on about charts Al Gore style then gives out physics-based assignments (your only grades) with no relevance to lecture. Don't take.

Those who actually attended class usually fell asleep after 10 minutes.  The lectures are basically powerpoints and the poor guy seems depressed all the time.  Seems like he loathes teaching basic astronomy to apathetic freshmen.  Some classmates found it tough, so only take it if you're good at the sciences.
This was a first year seminar on energy, and it wasn't good.  I would not recommend taking the class.  Professor Cecil knows what he's talking about, but he wasn't good at getting us to know it.
really hard tests. he's a funny guy, but a really boring class. you don't have to go to class, but it might help, i didn't go b/c i couldn't stay awake.

There isn't much class work involved in this class. We sometimes had one assignment due per week. The tests seem impossible but there is a pretty generous curve. This class is interesting for the most part but I've fallen asleep multiple times in lecture.
No Comments

He's very scatter-brained and teaches in a very rushed manner. You never know what to expect from him - he forgot our only test and cancelled our semester project. Homework is generally easy except 1 impossible problem. The class is very generously graded. He leaves the country frequently but checks his email freuqently, fortunately.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: I love him! Great professor! He could be a really cool uncle!

An absolutely amazing professor. Extremely entertaining, knows the material, and is more than happy to help out and clarify when a subject or topic isn't quite clear. Has a great personality and is very personable and enjoys interacting with students. If given the opportunity, you should take a class with this professor.

Hands down the best professor I've ever had. This is the second course I've had with him and both were amazing. He takes great interest in the material. He goes deep with concepts so you really understand them instead of trying to cover an entire book. Very clear and helpful. Tests aren't bad at all - some multiple choice, some problems.

Probably the only grad class I ever took where I never - not once - left class confused.  Any momentary confusion of quickly cleared up with a well answered question.  It's not that the class was easy - he just explains things so well.  And he takes a real interest in his students.  One of the best profs I've ever had.

Great professor! Really cares that the student understands the concepts. Tests are kinda hard but he tests on exactly what he teaches, nothing extra. Definitely go to class, don't bother with the book. One of the best professors I've had at UNC!
No Comments

Easy tests if you understand the basic concepts but tough homework and subject matter. Attendance not required but missing class is generally bad. Truly loves his field and explains things as clearly as possible. be prepared to sit through some intense math at times though. Excellent prof overall.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Go to review sessions, they help a ton. Once you figure out what he expects the class is rewarding. I'm no physics major- so I learned a lot and found it really interesting. A good teacher, even with sometimes difficult subject matter.

Seems nice on the outside but after attending all review sessions during the semester he wouldnt cut me a break on the final grade over a difference on less than 1%...never curved exams either...grading structure on exams very questionable...HORRIBLE LAST IMPRESSION
I nearly failed his class due to some personal trauma but Superfine did everything he could to help me get credit for his course.  He is a great guy and his class is as fun as any other on campus.
A really cool, down to earth teacher but his blackboard stuff is a pain in the ass!
Prof. Superfine is awesome. He is funny....and makes learning fun and easy
He was a fabulous teacher. Was lively and animateed every class. GO TO OFFICE HOURS! They are SO helpful! I would highly recommend this course to everyone.
makes classes fun and interesting. definitely go to his office hours, very helpful.
Excellent teacher, not too hard, especially if you know what hes looking for. Easily the best class and teacher I have had here.
pain in the ass with his grading
Definitely an interesting class, but it is extremely hard.  Lots of homework assignments and difficult tests.  He's very personable and makes class interesting and enjoyable with demos.

He's really animated and funny!  His class is never boring and he obviously cares very much about his students.  He makes you as interested in physics as he is.  Definitely a good class to take, especially if you've never like physics before.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Wu is a very nice man, and wants the class to do well. The only problem is that he's not good at helping the class do well. One lecture might cover a whole chapter, another might cover one or two sections of a chapter. He spends too long on derivations, and not enough time ensuring class understanding. Prepare to teach yourself

Considering the overall quality of teachers in this department, he's not bad.  He knows his stuff, but is not very clear so you don't loose much by not coming.  Schroeder's book was very helpful...usually much clearer than Wu.  Tests are not very difficult.  Fair in partial credit, so at least put down the correct formula if you are out of time.
Great professor and great person. Once you get over accent, very very helpful. Let class go because only few people showed up after a 21st b-day celebration :) .
Hard, but not difficult to understand. His tests are not impossible if you study well. Also, be sure to do the homework, since it is a large part of your grade.
I have not heard one student say they liked his class (out of dozens).

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Worst class I have ever taken at UNC. This is a pre req for med schools and dental schools and most people in there are taking this class for that reason. This class is extremely tough and they do not try to help or explain things well at all. If you can take it somewhere else do it! I made the mistake of taking it here and now have to repeat it.
He is a nice person and I have found him to be more helpful in one-on-one situations. The lectures are not particularly helpful, since you are expected to do the bulk of your learning in studio.

Terrible lecturer. Disorganized. The Physics department is terrible, and he is apart of this mess. You'll never know what you're doing, and their terrible explanations won't help at all. Good luck! Also, they have no official textbook so good luck finding what you need to know!

Professor Tsui was so convoluted in his explanations for problems, it left me even more confused. He goes above and beyond in his lectures, so be prepared. His exams are the hardest I have ever taken here, even after taking orgo and biochemistry. Be prepared.

reading the textbook is a must. he's a nice guy but not the greatest teacher. tests can be hard but he curves pretty generously. write down all the examples and demonstrations in your notes; they often appear on tests

I found this class to be very difficult. The tests were extremely hard and I struggled most of the time. Frank is a cool guy and knows his stuff. Class was entertaining sometimes and deathly boring the other times. The TA was absolutely worthless, I dont think she engaged anyone in the class at any point.

The lectures are fairly boring to someone who isn't interested in physics.  Attendance is required because of the iClickers as a part of your grade.  Tests are challenging but he curves generously.  HW is assigned often and there are online quizzes.  English is not his strength, but it's fine. The class is not overly difficult and is manageable.

Demonstrations in class work 45% of the time. His English is his second language, so sometimes it's hard to understand him. His tests are ALL short answer (*not sure about the Final though.) Many opportunities for grades; participation, homework, home experiments, pretests and exams, however it's a lot of work.

Very easy to understand. He had some great in-class demonstrations too. The only things that bugged me were the clickers for attendance. Make sure you get a friend to pick your up for class if you're going to skip.
A lot harder than i thought it would be!

Great teacher if you are interested in Physics. He is fun and makes sure to include the class in discussions/lectures. His teaching style might make it hard for a student who is not interested in Physics. Taking AP Physics makes this extremely easy.

Does not explain his lectures very well in class, instead preferring to discuss concepts over doing actual example problems.  Reading the textbook will be a must as you will probably not learn the material any other way.  His tests are also poorly worded and described.  Would be better if he could actually explain his lecture material.
-VERY hard professor, but explains stuff really well. -HW = USELESS

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Had Professor Falvo last year. He's very helpful professor and very clear. If you get to know him, he is a great man. Definitely ask him about his research in the lab regarding his prothrombin blood. The class itself is not too demanding; there are no textbooks. Just make sure you do the readings for the quizzes and you'll be set.
Interesting class. Not an easy first year seminar.
Fascinating nanotechnology class, he gives a bunch of interesting work, not too hard but not easy, enjoyable
Great class/ teacher.
Very clear and helpful, low-key class.
